title: Ask HN: Security Lab in the Cloud – Options?
text:
I work for a security team in a large multinational, and I'm looking for a completely off-net security lab service.

Our internal network has a lot of security protections like network proxies, internal PKI, etc. This means that if we want to do some pentesting exercises and trying out new security software we need to spend more time jumping through our own hoops than doing the actual exercise, even though we don't even need to be on the company network for it.

Just to connect to the internet from a docker container is a large amount of work which makes it very hard to quickly test out a new solution. Also, we oftend trigger our own internal security mechanisms leading to false positives.

I'm looking for companies offering a completely cloud-based "security lab as a service", where we can spin up a playground of possibly vulnerable machines, try out new security software on a simulated company etc.

I'm not considering AWS and Azure for this as those are already managed by other people in our company and subject to the same restrictions and approvals. Also, I wonder if we would trigger their own IDSes (Intrusion detection systems) if we start doing pentest exercises.

I assume I'm not the only one dealing with this issue so I was hoping to hear something about what others are doing.

Ask HN: What nuggets are stored offline on your computer?
text:
I just watched Hikaru's latest analysis of the current ongoing chess drama regarding OTB cheating. There he nearly revealed by accident some of his personal files and analyses while opening his chessbase database during the stream.

This made me think and I realized that I also have some proprietary stuff (specific data format descriptions and code snippets mainly) that are presumably _valuable_, in any case definitely worthy for my job/business.

So, I'm curious: How does it look for you? Would you be ruined in case someone got access to your personal files, or are we living in a post-privacy world by now in this regard?

Ask HN: Founders who went through VC funding, what was the hardest thing?
text:
Hi everyone, I'm trying to build a project that solves pain point of start-ups trying to raise capital through VCs.

I'm starting with understanding what it goes to create a pitch deck and what is the most common problem with it.

If you ever sent or presented a pitch deck, what did you find the most difficult thing to do? Did you rely on an external consultant to craft and design the deck or did you create it yourself?

Thank you in advance.
